summary: Applied geophysicist with a passion for innovation. I am committed to a more sustainable and efficient world using smart technologies. Extracting as much information as possible from seismograms to build high-resolution seismic images drives most of my research in exploration seismology. To better understand geological processes, geoscientists use 3D maps to retrieve information from interiors otherwise inaccessible. In particular, my research aim at finding ways to apply Marchenko Imaging in complex tectonic setups by bridging the gaps between the theoretical developments and the specific case of study in real scenarios.

DIME grant number 12948', 'contributors': [{'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'David', 'last_name': 'Vargas', 'name': None, 'headline': 'PhD Candidate at Utrecht University'}]}, {'title': 'Seismo-Live: computational Seismology with Jupyter Notebooks', 'date': {'start': {'month': None, 'day': None, 'year': None}, 'end': {'month': None, 'day': None, 'year': None}}, 'description': 'This project presents a community-driven library of Jupyter notebooks dedicated to various topics and training on seismology for research and educational purposes. My main contribution can be summarized in terms of seismic wavefields modeling with python. The methods include finite differences, pseudospectral methods, finite elements, spectral elements, finite volumes and the discontinuous Galerkin method.
